*Z‖agilemanifesto‖SI‖En‖The Manifesto for Agile Software Development is based on twelve principles:`n`n1. Customer satisfaction by early and continuous delivery of valuable software.`n2. Welcome changing requirements
column2: even in late development.`n3. Deliver working software frequently (weeks rather than months).`n4. Close
column3: daily cooperation between business people and developers.`n5. Projects are built around motivated individuals
column4: who should be trusted.`n6. Face-to-face conversation is the best form of communication (co-location).`n7. Working software is the primary measure of progress.`n8. Sustainable development
column5: able to maintain a constant pace.`n9. Continuous attention to technical excellence and good design.`n10. Simplicity—the art of maximizing the amount of work not done—is essential.`n11. Best architectures
column7: and designs emerge from self-organizing teams.`n12. Regularly
column8: the team reflects on how to become more effective

*Z‖bloomstaxonomy/‖SI‖En‖Bloom's Taxonomy is a set of three hierarchical models used for classification of educational learning objectives into levels of complexity and specificity. The three lists cover the learning objectives in cognitive
column2: affective and psychomotor domains. The cognitive domain list has been the primary focus of most traditional education and is frequently used to structure curriculum learning objectives
column3: assessments and activities.`n`nremember: recall facts and basic concepts (define
column17: translate)`napply: use information in new situations (execute
column34: test)`nevaluate: justify a stand or decision (appraise
column42: weigh)`ncreate: produce new or original work (design

*Z‖dorametrics/‖SI‖En‖Deployment Frequency — How often an organization successfully releases to production.`n`nLead Time for Changes — The amount of time it takes a commit to get into production.`n`nChange Failure Rate — The percentage of deployments causing a failure in production.`n`nTime to Restore Service — How long it takes an organization to recover from a failure in production.‖
*Z‖efficiency/‖SI‖En‖efficiency`n1. Doing something unimportant prevents you from doing something important.`n`n2. A time-intensive task doesn't become important just because of it.‖
*Z‖happiness/‖SI‖En‖What you want in your life: `n`n1. relationships`n2. work`n3. money`n4. health (physical
column3: spiritual ← deeper sense of meaning)`n`n(4x circles must be balanced)‖

*Z‖rocketmodel/‖SI‖En‖Results: The team's track record.`nIs the team delivering on its commitsments? Does it accomplish important goals
column3: and improve over time?`n`nCourage: The team's approach to managing conflicts.`nDo team members feel safe raising difficult issues and does conflict get managed effectively?`n`nResources: the team's assets.`nDoes the team have the necessary physical and monetary resources
column4: authority and political support?`n`nBuy-In: The level of motivation among team members.`nAre team members optimistic about the team's chances for winning and motivated to accomplish the team's goals?`n`nNorms: The team's formal and informal work processes.`nDoes the team use effective and efficient processes for running meetings
column6: and getting work done?`n`nTalent: the people who make up this team.`nDoes this team have the right nummber of people
column8: and does it have the skills needed to succeed?`n`nMission: The team's purpose and goals.`nWhy does the team exist? How does it define winning
column9: and what are its strategies for accomplishing goals?`n`nContext: The situation in which the team operates.`nDo team members agree about the team's political and economic realities

column1: *Z‖selfdiscrepancyhiggings‖SI‖En‖The theory postulates three basic domains of the self:`n`nActual self is one's representation of the attributes that one believes one actually possesses
column2: or that one believes others believe one possesses. The "actual self" is a person's basic self-concept. It is one's perception of their own attributes (intelligence
column5: etc.).`n`nIdeal self is one's representation of the attributes that someone (oneself or another) would like one
column10: or wishes for one).[4] The "ideal-self" is what usually motivates individuals to change
column11: improve and achieve.`n`nThe ideal self-regulatory system focuses on the presence or absence of positive outcomes (e.g.
column12: love provided or withdrawn).`n`nOught is one's representation of the attributes that someone (oneself or another) believes one should or ought to possess (i.e.
column13: a representation of someone's sense of one's duty
column15: or responsibilities). The ought self-regulatory system focuses on the presence or absence of negative outcomes (e.g.

*Z‖valuesrs/‖SI‖En‖voestalpine Railway Systems values:`n`nCOURAGE – We dare. We think out of the box to overcome limits
column2: take calculated risks and challenges to explore the unknown.`n`nCURIOSITY – We explore. We welcome personal
column4: drive them and grow with them.`n`nDIVERSITY – We include. We are mindful of including
column5: valuing and leveraging the individual characteristics
column6: talents and experiences of a diverse team to achieve excellent results.`n`nPASSION – We excite. We enthusiastically work with our hearts to exceed our customers expectations.`n`nRESPECT – We appreciate. We appreciate different perspectives
column9: humble and honest way and fully trust each other.`n`nRESPONSIBILITY – We own. We bear the consequences of our actions – therefore we control the success.‖
